metadata.title: Synthesis of Co3O4-NiO nano-needles for amperometric sensing of glucose

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Electroanalytical Chemistry
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jelechem
Synthesis of Co3O4-NiO nano-needles for amperometric sensing of glucose Yajun Gaoa,b,1, Qianhui Yua,1, Yitian Dua, Ming Yanga, Lu Gaoa, Shengqi Raoa, Zhenquan Yanga, Qingchun Lanb, Zhanjun Yangb,⁎
a School of Food Science and Technology, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou, Jiangsu 225127, PR China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou, Jiangsu 225002, PR China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Glucose Co3O4-NiO composites Nonenzymatic electrochemical sensors Human serum
A B S T R A C T
In this paper, needle-like Co3O4-NiO nanocomposites with excellent electrocatalytic activity were served as electrode matrix for constructing novel electrochemical glucose sensor. The Co3O4-NiO nanocomposites were synthesized via a simple two-step procedure, showing a uniform geometric size with average length and diameter about 465 and 25 nm, respectively. The Co3O4-NiO composites exhibited random distributed nano-needles were investigated by scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction and Xray photoelectron spectroscopy. In addition, the needle-like Co3O4-NiO nanocomposites were used as an electrode material for constructing nonenzymatic electrochemical glucose sensor and their electrocatalytic performances were evaluated by cyclic voltammetry and amperometry techniques. The sensor exhibited a wide linear response in the 1 μM to 3.4 mM and 3.4 mM to 12.2 mM glucose concentration ranges, a low detection limit of 0.81 μM and a high sensitivity of 62 mA M−1 cm−2 (S/N = 3). Furthermore, the prepared sensor was utilized to detect the glucose levels in human serum, and satisfactory results were obtained. It demonstrated that needlelike Co3O4-NiO nanocomposites are promising materials in practical electrochemical sensing.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Glucose monitoring is of great importance in many fields, including clinical diagnostics, food analysis, and biotechnology [1–3]. In particular, the blood glucose monitoring for clinical diagnosis and treatment of diabetes has greatly promoted the development of many glucose analytical methods [4,5]. Over the past years, a number of various approaches have been developed to detect glucose such as chromatography, colorimetry, fluorescence and electrochemical methods [6–9]. Among them, the electrochemical methods are one of the most promising techniques because of its high sensitivity, good selectivity and without complex preliminary separation process [10,11]. Conventionally, the glucose oxidase based glucose sensors exhibit high sensitivity and selectivity. However, due to the intrinsic feature of enzymes, the activity of the glucose oxidase can be easily affected by environment factors, including humidity, temperature, pH value, organic reagents and toxic chemicals [12–15]. Therefore, great effort has been paid to the establishment of nonenzymatic glucose sensors with the advantages of low cost and high stability.
With the rapid development of nanomaterials and nanofabrication technology in the past decades, various inorganic complexes have been
employed as the electrocatalysts for glucose electro-oxidization. Previous researches mainly focused on the use of noble metals such as Au and Pt [16,17] and their metal complexes such as Pt-CuO [18] and AuRu [19] modified electrodes. These noble metals as electrocatalysts for glucose electro-oxidization showed high electrocatalytic activities and good sensitivity. However, there are some critical issues with noble metal based glucose sensors. The unbalanced distribution and the high cost of noble metal resources drastically limit their commercial applications. Apart from this, they faced with the problems that they are susceptible to the contamination of chemisorbed intermediates and adsorbed chloride ions [20]. The aforementioned problems with noble metal based glucose sensors have facilitated the concentration on the utilization of easily available and low cost metal and their metal oxide materials such as Co3O4, NiO, Cu and CuO [21–24] for the construction of nonenzymatic glucose sensors. Among these various metal and metal oxides, Co3O4 is an important transition metal oxide and magnetic ptype semiconductor. Despite the relatively poor electrical conductivity of pure Co3O4, Co3O4-based nanocomposites have acquired extensively research interest due to their chemical stable, low cost and relatively good electrocatalytic properties [25–30]. NiO is kind of common-seen and bargain-priced material. NiO has been considered as an effective
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jelechem.2019.02.049 Received 30 November 2018; Received in revised form 31 January 2019; Accepted 26 February 2019
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: zjyang@yzu.edu.cn (Z. Yang). 1 These authors contributed equally to this work.
Journal of Electroanalytical Chemistry 838 (2019) 41–47
Available online 27 February 2019 1572-6657/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
electrocatalyst for oxidation of glucose [31,32] because of its impressed catalytic activity, which results from the redox couple of Ni III/Ni II in alkaline media. However, NiO-based nonenzymatic sensors show low durability due to gradual dissolution and detachment of the catalyst from substrates [33]. Therefore, many researchers recently focused on the modification of NiO with support materials such as metal oxides and carbon materials to acquire a satisfying catalytic performance [34–36]. Since the mechanism of a nonenzymatic glucose sensor is based on the direct oxidation of glucose by high valence metal ions on the electrode, more exposed electrocatalytic active sites of electrode material should be highly favorable for the enhanced performance of sensors [37]. Therefore, combining NiO with Co3O4 as the electrode material may be an effective approach to tackle their respective adverse impact and thus to enhance the overall catalytic performance for nonenzymatic sensors.
Herein, in this paper, Co3O4-NiO nano-needles were prepared using a simple two-step method. The morphology and structure of as-prepared nanocomposite were characterized using scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and amperometry experiment showed that the Co3O4-NiO nanocomposites exhibited higher electro-oxidation toward glucose as compared to Co3O4 nanomaterials (Scheme 1). It demonstrated that the proposed nanocomposites provide a promising matrix for glucose sensor applications.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and reagents
sections.text: D-(+)-Glucose and Nafion were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without any further purification. A stock solution of D-glucose was prepared and allowed to mutarotate at room temperature for 24 h before measurements. Ethanol, potassium ferricyanide(III) (K3[Fe(CN)6]), potassium hexacyanoferrate(II) (K4[Fe(CN)6]), cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni (NO3)2·6H2O), ethylene glycol, uric acid (UA), urea (U), ascorbic acid (AA), 4-Acetamldophenol (AP), sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and potassium chloride (KCl) were obtained from Sinoparm Chemical Reagent Beijing Co., Ltd. All other chemicals and reagents are of analytical grade and prepared using the distilled water.

sections.heading: 2.2. Apparatus
sections.text:
Electrochemical measurements were carried on a CHI852C electrochemical workstation (Shanghai CH Instruments Co., China). All electrochemical experiments were performed with a three-electrode system using a glassy carbon electrode (GCE) as a working electrode, a platinum wire as the auxiliary electrode and Ag/AgCl electrode as reference electrode. CV experiments were carried out at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1 in an electrochemical cell filled with 0.1 M of NaOH.
XRD patterns were performed with a D8 advance X-ray diffractometer from Bruker Co. (Germany). XPS was performed on an ESCALAB250Xi spectrometer (USA). The morphologies of the as-prepared samples were observed using a field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) at an acceleration voltage of 5.0 kV. TEM images were captured on the transmission electron microscope (JEM-2100). High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images, energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrum were captured on the Tecnai G2 F30 transmission electron microscope (acceleration voltage: 300 kV).

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of needle-like Co3O4/NiO nanocomposite with rough surface
sections.text:
A typical procedure of the synthesis of needle-like Co3O4/NiO
nanocomposites is as follow: Firstly, cobalt nitrate (2.33 g), nickel nitrate (0.21 g) and urea (40.0 mmol) were dissolved in a mixture of 40 mL ethylene glycol and 40 mL distilled water. After stirring for 30 min, the mixture was transformed into a teflon-lined autoclave and reacted at 120 °C for 12 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solid products were collected by centrifugation at 4000 rpm for 10 min and washed several times with ethanol and distilled water, and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 4 h. Secondly, the product was obtained by annealing at 500 °C in air for 4 h, and the heating rate was 5 °C min−1. The sample was denoted P3. Synthesis of other Co3O4 − NiO weight ratio samples were similar to the above procedures except the variation of the amounts of Co3O4 and NiO. The detailed synthesis parameters are shown in Table S1.

sections.heading: 2.4. Preparation of the glucose sensor
sections.text: The GCE was firstly polished successively with 0.3 μm and 0.05 μm alumina slurry (Buhler) followed by rinsing thoroughly with distilled water, successive ultrasonication in 1:1 nitric acid, acetone and distilled water and dried in air. 1.0 mg of the prepared Co3O4-NiO nanocomposite was firstly dispersed in 1.0 mL distilled water with sonication for 30 min. Then 5.0 μL aqueous dispersion was dropped on the cleaned GCE and dried at room temperature. Then the electrodes were finally obtained after 5.0 μL 0.5% Nafion was dropped on surface of the modified electrodes. (Fig. S1 illustrate the influence of amount of Co3O4-NiO nanocomposites on the oxidation peak currents of 0.4 mM glucose). The fabricated electrodes were rinsed thoroughly to remove the loosely absorbed Nafion molecules. The modified electrodes were stored at 4 °C in a refrigerator when not in use.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterizations of the Co3O4-NiO nanocomposite
sections.text:
Fig. 1a and b show the SEM and TEM images of the synthesized Co3O4-NiO (sample P3). It could be found that the nanocomposites exhibit uniform geometric size with high porosity. The average length and diameter of the nano-needles are about 465 and 25 nm, respectively. In HRTEM image (Fig. 1c), lattice fringes with interplanar spacings of 0.287 nm and 0.212 nm are observed, corresponding to the (220) plane of Co3O4 and the (200) face of NiO, respectively. The corresponding elemental mapping images (Fig. 1d–g) and the EDX spectra (Fig. 1h) of as-synthesized samples indicated that these Co3O4NiO nanocomposites are mainly consisted of Co, Ni and O elements. The powder XRD measurements were used to investigate the crystal structure and phase purity of the obtained samples. As shown in Fig. 1i, the Co3O4 nanoparticles display characteristic peaks at 18.1°, 31.3°, 36.9°, 44.8°, 55.8°, 59.4°, 65.3°, and 76.4°, which are corresponding to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), (440) and (620) crystal planes. These peaks are corroborated with standard patterns of Co3O4 (JCPDS 42-1467) [38]. The NiO nanoparticles exhibited the characteristic diffraction peaks at 38.2°, 43.3°, 63.4°, 75.4° and 79.3°, which are in good agreement with (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) planes of NiO in cubic lattice (JCPDS 71-1179) [39,40]. The XRD spectrum of the prepared Co3O4-NiO composites matches the spectrum of Co3O4 nanoparticles and NiO nanoparticles. However, it is difficult to find the typical peaks of NiO in the Co3O4-NiO composites, which might be attributed to the relatively low content and poor crystallinity of NiO. No other impurity phases observed from the XRD analysis ensured the structural purity of the prepared samples.
XPS was further analyzing the element information of the Co3O4NiO nanocomposite. As shown in Fig. 2a, the XPS survey spectrum of as-synthesized Co3O4-NiO indicates that these Co3O4-NiO nanocomposites are mainly consisted of Co, Ni and O elements. The XPS survey spectrum of Ni 2p exhibits two contributions, 2p1/2 and 2p3/2, located at 855.2 eV and 873.5 eV respectively (Fig. 2b), confirming the
presence of NiO species in the product [41]. Besides, the two typical binding energy peaks of Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 at 794.6 and 780.3 eV with a separation of 14.3 eV, respectively (Fig. 2c), are assigned to (Co2+/Co3+) [42]. The O 1 s peak at 531.3 eV is related to hydroxyl group, and the peak at 529.7 eV is ascribed to lattice oxygen (Fig. 4d).

sections.heading: 3.2. Direct electrochemistry of Co3O4-NiO/GCE
sections.text:
To investigate the electrocatalytic activity of as-synthesized Co3O4NiO nanocomposite toward glucose oxidation, Co3O4-NiO nano-needles were dispersed in Nafion/ethanol solution and modified onto GCE. Fig.
S2 shows the electrochemical behavior of different samples (P1-P4 GCEs) in a 0.4 mM glucose solution. It illustrates that the oxidation and reduction peaks of the sample P3 GCE (the weight ratio of Co3O4 and NiO is 100:9) is higher than those of other modified GCEs under the same conditions. Thus, P3 material is chosen as the target material and the Co3O4-NiO/GCE represent P3 GCE in the following discussion. The electrochemical behaviors of bare GCE, NiO/GCE, Co3O4/GCE and Co3O4-NiO/GCE were analyzed by using CV technique in 0.1 M NaOH electrolyte in the potential range of 0.2 to 0.7 V. As shown in Fig. 3A, the bare GCE showed no noticeable catalytic effects toward the glucose electro-oxidation in current alkaline medium. While NiO/GCE and
Co3O4/GCE have revealed weak redox peaks owing to the presence of metal catalysts. Previous studies have revealed that there are two redox reactions for Co3O4/GCE in NaOH solution [43–45]. One pair of redox peak can be assigned to the reversible reaction between Co3O4 and CoOOH, while the other pair of redox peak can be assigned to the reversible reaction between CoOOH and CoO2. The reactions can be schematically expressed as follows:
+ + +Co O OH H O 3CoOOH e3 4 – 2 (1)
+ + +CoOOH OH CoO H O e– 2 2 (2)
+ +2CoO glucose 2CoOOH gluconolactone2 (3)
In addition, previous results also point out that, the redox peak current for reaction (2) is much stronger than redox peak for reaction (1). In certain cases, two reduction reaction can't be separated thoroughly due to the overlapping of reduction peaks, and the peak for reaction from Co3O4/CoOOH can't be clearly observed [28,46]. Therefore, It is acceptable that the peak potential of CoOOH/CoO2 (peak for reaction (2)) is usually applied for subsequent amperometric detection. For the Co3O4/GCE in the figure, our result has exhibited the prompt current Ipa (anode peak) of 21 μA at 0.58 V vs. Ag/AgCl, which is ascribed to the peak for reaction from CoOOH/CoO2. For the Co3O4NiO/GCE in the presence of 0.4 mM glucose, a dramatic prompt Ipa prompt currents Ipa is 50 μA at 0.52 V vs. Ag/AgCl, which is much higher as compared to the Co3O4/GCE and NiO/GCE, probably owing to the higher catalytic activity of composite nano-needles through the synergetic effects of NiO and Co3O4 [47,48]. This redox peak is an integrated redox couple owing to the integration of redox couple of NiO/ NiOOH and CoOOH/CoO2 because these two redox couples show similar reaction potentials. The electrocatalysis process of glucose is irreversible. And the reactions can be presumably proposed according to the following:
+ +2CoO glucose 2CoOOH gluconolactone2 (4)
+ +2NiOOH glucose 2NiO gluconolactone (5)
Fig. 3B shows the CVs of Co3O4-NiO/GCE using different concentration of glucose. The concentration of glucose varies from 0 to 4.8 mM caused the obvious increase of Ipa with increasing glucose concentration. It demonstrates that glucose can be easily oxidized on the surface of cobalt‑nickel oxides over a wide concentration window which guaranteeing its amperometric glucose sensing applications. Moreover, the electrokinetics involved in the proposed electrode was examined by different scan rates. Fig. 4A displays the CVs of Co3O4NiO/GCE in the presence of 0.4 mM glucose at different scan rates ranging from 10 to 100 mV s−1 in 0.1 M NaOH solution. With the increase of the scan rates, the Epa and Epc (cathode peak potential) were slightly shifted to positive and negative values, respectively. Furthermore, Fig. 4B displays that both Ipa and Ipc (cathode peak current) were
proportional to the square root of the scan rate, with the high correlation coefficient (R2) of 0.9989 (Ipa) and 0.9941 (Ipc) respectively, suggesting that this electrocatalytic process is controlled by the diffusion of glucose to the electrolyte/electrode interface, thus depending on the concentration of glucose in solution.

sections.heading: 3.3. Optimization of experimental conditions
sections.text: The applied potential has a critical impact on the sensing performance of the glucose sensor. Fig. S3 displays the influence of the applied potential on the current response of Co3O4-NiO modified GCE toward 0.1 mM glucose in a range from 0.40 to 0.60 V. It can be seen that the maximum current response is obtained when the potential is 0.55 V. Thus, the potential of 0.55 V was chosen as the optimum applied potential in the following experiments.

sections.heading: 3.4. Amperometric detection of glucose at Co3O4-NiO/GCE
sections.text: Amperometric analysis was used to study the analytical performance of the proposed glucose sensor due to its high sensitivity, convective mass transport and rapid detection toward the oxidation of glucose. Fig. 5A showed the typical amperometric responses of Co3O4NiO/GCE on the successive step-wise addition of glucose into the stirring NaOH solution. When a certain concentration of glucose was added at a regular time intervals of 50 s into above solution, a rapid current increment can be observed. The corresponding calibration curves of the proposed Co3O4-NiO/GCE sensor are described in Fig. 5B, which displays two linear response from 1 μM to 3.4 mM (correlation coefficient R2 = 0.9916) and 3.4 mM to 12.2 mM (correlation coefficient R2 = 0.9922). The above two linear ranges can be explained by the different diffusion rates of reaction products under the different glucose concentrations. When in low concentration of glucose, the oxidation products can quickly leave away from the surface of electrode. Nevertheless, the high concentrations of glucose obstruct the diffusion of the gluconolactone. As a result, lower oxidation peak current is detected in the high concentration range and relatively higher oxidation current existed in low concentration of glucose. The limit of detection (LOD) of the Co3O4-NiO nanocomposite based sensor was estimated to be 0.81 μM and the sensitivity is calculated to be 62 mA·M−1·cm−2 (S/

sections.heading: N = 3).
sections.text: Moreover, the performance of proposed sensor is compared to that of reported glucose nonenzymatic electrochemical sensors (Table 1). It can be shown that the performance of the proposed sensor in this work is better than most previous studies in terms of sensitivity and LOD. The high electrocatalytic performance is ascribed to its increased electroactive sites, efficiently accelerating the electron transfer rate between the electrode and electrolyte during glucose oxidation.

sections.heading: 3.5. Interference, reproducibility and stability studies
sections.text:
To study the reproducibility of the developed sensor, the Co3O4NiO/GCE was measured under ten injections of 10 μM glucose. As shown in Fig. 6A, the sensor exhibits an obvious and equivalent increase after each injection, which indicates the good repeatability of the sensor. The stability of the glucose sensor was investigated by analysis the current responses periodically. The modified electrodes were stored at room temperature, and the current response measurements were performed with 1 mM glucose at an interval of every 3 days. Fig. 6B displays the investigation results, the current response remains at about 92% of its initial value, demonstrating high stability of the designed glucose sensor. The above results demonstrate that the fabricated sensor system has relatively good reproducibility and longtime stability. Selectivity test is an important parameter for glucose sensors, electroactive species such as ascorbic acid (AA), acetaminophen (AP) and uric acid (UA) commonly coexist in human serum, although the
concentration of these electroactive species are much lower than glucose. In this work, the anti-interference ability of the proposed sensor for quantitative detection of glucose was tested using 0.1 mM AA, 0.1 mM AP and 0.1 mM UA (Fig. 7). Firstly, a clear current response could be observed when 0.1 mM glucose was added to electrolyte solution. While the successive injection of AA, AP and UA to the system, the current response exhibited no appreciable changes. When 0.1 mM glucose was added to the system again, an obvious current response appeared, suggesting that the proposed glucose sensor embodies a good anti-interference property.

sections.heading: 3.6. Detection of glucose in human serum samples
sections.text:
The practical applicability of the glucose sensor was investigated by measuring clinical serum samples and the results were compared with the reference method. The reference values were provided by Yangzhou Youhao hospital. The results were listed in Table 2 (each sample was
measured five times). It showed the relative errors between two methods were no more than 6.2%, indicating the fabricated glucose sensor has a good accuracy for clinical practical samples.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In this work, novel Co3O4-NiO nano-needles were prepared for the nonenzymatic glucose sensor probes. The as-synthesized nanocomposites show excellent electrocatalytic activity toward the glucose oxidation served as electrode matrix to construct non-enzymatic glucose sensor displaying excellent sensitivity and remarkable selectivity to glucose. The combination of Co3O4 with NiO highly improves the electrochemical performance of the glucose sensor. The Co3O4-NiO nano-needles were characterized by the electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, energy disperse spectroscopy mapping and cyclic voltammetry. Moreover, the constructed sensor showed high sensitivity, wide linear range, good reproducibility, and high selectivity. The consistent results of this proposed sensor and the commercial method for the detection of human serum samples indicates the potential advantages in practical application.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: The funding of this work was provided by National Natural Science Foundation of China (no. 21575125, 21475116 and 31371806). In addition, much thanks to The Testing Center of Yangzhou University due to all the characterizations.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sections.text: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.jelechem.2019.02.049.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, needle-like Co3O4-NiO nanocomposites with excellent electrocatalytic activity were served as electrode matrix for constructing novel electrochemical glucose sensor. The Co3O4-NiO nanocomposites were synthesized via a simple two-step procedure, showing a uniform geometric size with average length and diameter about 465 and 25 nm, respectively. The Co3O4-NiO composites exhibited random distributed nano-needles were investigated by scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction and Xray photoelectron spectroscopy. In addition, the needle-like Co3O4-NiO nanocomposites were used as an electrode material for constructing nonenzymatic electrochemical glucose sensor and their electrocatalytic performances were evaluated by cyclic voltammetry and amperometry techniques. The sensor exhibited a wide linear response in the 1 μM to 3.4 mM and 3.4 mM to 12.2 mM glucose concentration ranges, a low detection limit of 0.81 μM and a high sensitivity of 62 mA M−1 cm−2 (S/N = 3). Furthermore, the prepared sensor was utilized to detect the glucose levels in human serum, and satisfactory results were obtained. It demonstrated that needlelike Co3O4-NiO nanocomposites are promising materials in practical electrochemical sensing.
